newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: FORECAST-Australian ACTU Living Wage award.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-Australian ACTU Living Wage award.

text.p: The "living wage" claim by unions is one of the most important developments in wages this year and could have profound implications for monetary policy in Australia.
The outcome of the case is due to be released Tuesday by the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC).

The living wage claim by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) asks for three A$20 a week pay increases over the next three years for workers who have failed to negotiate an enterprise bargaining agreement, and also for an 8.75 percent increase in minimum award pay rates this year.
Economists were asked what they expect the weekly rise granted by the IRC to be, and if they expect the 8.75 percent increase claim to be successful or not.
Economists said the ACTU's claim was an ambit one, just as the government's offer of an A$8 a week safety net rise was.
If the safety net was to keep the wages of lower paid workers in line with wages, than a rise of 10-12 dollars would probably be in order, given the CPI rose 1.5 percent in 1996.

The claim for an across-the-board increase in minimum award rate is unlikely to be successful, given the push for low inflation and the opposition to it from business the government and the Reserve Bank of Australia.
The best case scenario would be for a partial granting of the 8.75 percent claim, but even that was seen as unlikely, although that was seen as the wild card in forecasting the outcome of the case.
A rise in line with expectations should not cause too much alarm to policymakers or markets, as economists said it would be consistent with wages growth remaining under 4.5 percent.
What will need to be watched is how the case outcome flows through to other workers and leads to a quickening in the pace of wages growth economy wide, they said.
Note - This survey was carried out on March 21
